title: Before 2018, will Russia and Cuba announce the reopening of the Lourdes Signals Intelligence Center?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

In July 2014, reports surfaced that Russia and Cuba agreed to reopen the facility for usage by Russian intelligence. However, "Russia Today" later removed their original story and replaced it with one denying there was such an agreement.

Some developments: http://www.periodicocubano.com/interes-ruso-reabrir-base-militar-cuba/ English translation: "Russia "could do with" a military base in Cuba, a few kilometers from the United States, the head of the Defense Committee of the Russian parliament, Vladimir Shamanov, told Sputnik. He signaled a note from mundo.sputniknews.com. In April 2016, Deputies Valeri Rashkin and Sergei Óbujov sent a letter to President Vladimir Putin and Defense Minister Sergei Shoigú, with the proposal to re-establish the Russian center of Lourdes in response to the US plans to deploy missiles in Turkey of Himars type. The Lourdes radioelectronic listening center was a Russian military base used to control communications in the US. It was founded in 1967 and closed in February 2002."
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Anyway, I may bump this up a bit next week depending on what Mr. Tangerine Man announces as his new Cuba policy.  Stay tuned.

Well on the one hand all the articles I found about the center are from at least six months ago, but on the other trump has increased the level of global geopolitical uncertainty and countries may respond provocatively. Based on how many years worth of articles I found referring to the center, it seems more like a boogeyman than a real priority for the Russian government. That said, both Cuba and Russia will have in 2017 strong reasons to poke at the US and this seems like an easy way to do it; particularly if trump reverses the Obama's thaw or does something to piss off the Russians.

I'm not sure why Cuba would want it, as it is moving toward friendlier relations with the US, which would be worth more money than the fees from Russia for Lourdes. And the only reason to announce it would be political. I can't see Cuba or Russia wanting to take this particular shot at the US.

The US will use the carrots of increased tourism and economic ties to encourage Cuba not to reopen the site. Sanctions against Cuba have an uncertain future, and cooperation with America will be better for Cuba than intelligence cooperation with Russia.

Such an "announcement" is now more a bargaining tool, a tool for diplomacy to be used by Russia and Cuba should mutual interests overlap requiring a statement to the US.  So long as both governments are ruled in their respective manners the need for regime preservation may mean an event or series of events pushes Cuba and Russia into an alignment of interest, even if temporary.

Assessing the kind of information that Lourdes can intercept is apparently becoming more challenging and less useful as more communications are sent by fibre networks.  The Lourdes centre was closed because it was getting too expensive to operate and presumably had outlived its usefulness. It is also reported that closing the centre was a condition of a debt forgiveness agreement in 2001.  However, it is also reported that Russia are currently constructing a SIGINT facility in Nicaragua and Reopening the Lourdes centre would certainly not be inconsistent with Putin's recent assertiveness although given the recent election hacking allegations it would be a big move.  
On the Cuban side, agreeing to reopen the facility would be seen as a slap in the face to the U.S and would be damaging to the two countries tentative new courtship.  The Cuban government would be walking a tightrope trying to rekindle relationships with both countries simultaneously.  There would be financial incentives for cooperating with the Russians but I think it's more likely that the Russians will encourage the Cuban government to operate the facility themselves and sell them any secrets of relevance.

Trump has expressed his disappointment with the deal struck by the Obama administration with the Cuban government and signalled that he would like to get a better deal for the US, so i think if it looked liked US-Cuban relations were on the back foot again the Cubans might be more inclined to agree to a reopening of Lourdes if the offer was there. 
Ultimately attach a low probability
(no change) If I were Putin (I'm not), I might be looking for chits to trade with the new US President. —especially since the latter claimed Russia would give back Crimea.

The Lourdes SIGINT (Signals Intelligence) facility, located near Havana, Cuba, was the largest facility of its kind operated by the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service or SVR, outside of Russia. Located less than 150 km (93 mi) from Key West, the facility covered 73 km2 (28 sq mi). Construction began in July 1962. The station was closed in August 2002. All station facilities were shut down, the buildings were abandoned and later reconstructed to become what is now the University of Information Science. At its peak during the Cold War, the facility was staffed by over 1,500 KGB, GRU, Cuban DGI, and Eastern Bloc technicians, engineers and intelligence operatives. In 2000, it was reported that China signed an agreement with the Cuban government to share use of the facility for its own intelligence agency. The base was closed in 2001. Russia had paid Cuba a $200m annual subsidy to this point since 1962. In July 2014, reports surfaced that Russia and Cuba agreed to reopen the facility for usage by Russian intelligence. However, "Russia Today" later removed their original story and replaced it with one denying there was such an agreement. 
Russia says it may reopen Soviet-era military bases in Cuba and Vietnam
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/07/russia-says-it-may-reopen-soviet-era-military-bases-in-cuba-and/

"Russia Is Reportedly Reopening Its Spy Base In Cuba". Business Insider. Retrieved 2014-07-18.
"Putin denies reopening of US-targeting listening post in Cuba". RT. Retrieved 2014-07-18.

COMMENTS:  Russia plans to reopen, Russia denies reopening.....  Putin credibility is not very high. He may just want to keep all his options open.

Russia looks at the Trump`s presidency as a perfect opportunity to re-establish the relationship. Re-opening of the Center is a provocative move, which could be considered as a response to the increase presence of NATO at the Baltic. Given the uncertainty of the US policy in regards to the cooperation with NATO, it would be highly unlikely that NATO will make such moves within a 1 year time frame. There will be several concessions that the Russian government will be prepared to give in order to normalise the relationship with the US. Re-opening of the Center, which was probably considered as a response to the increase presence of NATO near the Russian borders in 2014, would be seen as a highly provocative decision. Within the paradigm of today`s agenda of the Russian government (i.e re-establish the relationship) and the  interest of Cuban government in re-establishing the links with the US, re-opening is a highly improbable event in such a short period of time.

Probably not going to be announced.  
Putin denied it would be happening after his July 2014 visit to Havana. 
Alexander Shchetinin from Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs told Lenta.ru in March 2016 there are "No plans to open military bases in Cuba."
An unnamed source told Kommersant that negotiations to re-open the station were completed on Putin's visit to Havana.
On May 8, 2015, senior member of the State Duma Security Committee, Dmitry Gorovtsov was quoted in Russia Today - "I think that in the nearest future we can restore the radio intelligence base in Lourdes." To my untrained eye, the satellite imagery of the site on Google Maps looks like a university campus.  There is certainly no obvious evidence of an intention to place SIGINT equipment there.  Maybe they'll have to consider a different site altogether?

Putin clearly wants a changed relationship with the US when Trump takes office. Maintaining a Russian sphere of influence in eastern  Europe is Putin's first international priority and moving into Cuba would jeopardize that by antagonizing the hard liners in Trump's administration.

There have been rumours for a couple of years with nothing forthcoming with makes it seem unlikely. There is the question of what use would Lourdes be to the Russians. I am not an expert in the technical capabilities such a centre would allow but I suspect that it is too far away from the Northern US to provide additional local capability above that which can already be achieved from a distance. On the other hand it does provide a quiet opportunity to have a peak at Mar a Lago but probably not necessary. There is then also the political symbolism of the move. I am not sure it would be of significant practical use to "providing conditions conducive to the successful implementation of the policy of the Russian Federation in the sphere of security;" especially as Putin has been playing down cold war tones. Also following others arguments that it's not really in Cuba's interest I would place this as very unlikely.
Cuba needs US tourist money.  They can not risk this infusion of money.  Putin has nothing left to bribe the regime with that can offset US$.
Doubt Putin will risk friendlier relations with US under Trumpf.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Seems not to be a whole lot more than a rumor, so my base rate is low.

The fact that there have been stories in media close to Putin since 2014 that Russia and Cuba might re-open Lourdes would tend to suggest that it is unlikely. (Why would it be in RT and then removed if the story were true? I don't believe RT's brave investigating reporters would have come across this type of scoop and had the editor publish it without checking if he was supposed to with the security service.) In 2014 (in the BT - Before Trump - era) the story might have had some purpose in seeing what reaction Obama made. Since 2014 Cuba and the US have been moving toward normalising their relations, which is presumably worth a lot more than what Russia would pay Cuba to host Lourdes again. The original site has been reused since so that would add to the cost of reopening it. And with a friend in the White House (from 20th Jan) does Putin want to stir up the US Congress that presumably still has some members who are not as keen on Russia as Trump, and as Trump is not a fan of the Cuban government why would Putin want to remind Trump that Russia and Cuba are friends. On the basis that my friend's enemies are my enemies and my enemies enemies are my friends the relationship between a Trump US (enemy Cuba and hope to be friend Russia) gets very complicated. (But maybe Trump works on the idea that he does not have allies, he just has interests). 
As Russia seems to be able get access to US data by hacking and spoofing web sites and email accounts, maybe that is cheaper than bothering with reopening Lourdes.

With Russian FDI in Cuba projected as lower than US and NATO countries' one, the reopening of Lourdes remains highly unlikely. No preliminary military or intel arrangements have been made by the two countries to set the scene for that, unlike - reportedly - Nicaragua (http://freebeacon.com/national-security/moscow-building-spy-site-nicaragua/). Managua's base, if established, would supply the regional post Russia wants to create to project influence. For the reasons above (especially FDI), even Russian media see the reopening of Lourdes as unlikely. Example: http://www.utro.ru/articles/2016/11/08/1303754.shtml
Cuba can make money with tourism, why upset the USA for the Russians?
Putin is crazy and Raul is senile.
i judge it very likely, however it depends how the RU/US relations will progress in general. it will be definitely not a first priority item on the RU agenda

1) I think Cuba has more to gain economically from the US than from Russia
2) Although President Trump likely will cause higher levels of tension internationally, at least initially (first 6 months?, first year?) his mutual admiration club with Putin might mean the Russians are unlikely to do something so openly antagonistic.
3) A lot of uncertainty about "announce".  Even if they reopen the facility (gradually?), they might not "announce" its reopening (unless the announcement itself serves a political purpose).
This will be Russia's way of keeping pressure on the US.  Also, it will signal Cuba's independence of US influence.
Increasing by 5% considering consistently assertive geopolitical posture by Russia, and timeline for aggressions (2008-Georgia; 2014-Crimea).

- Need: while SIGINT is conveniently obtained from a strategically placed station, Russia appears to have prominently strengthened other forms of collection over the past decade, downgrading the need for this base.
- Cost/Benefit: a station formerly hosting 3.000 staff, and abandoned for 15 years, would cost millions of $ to revamp, populate, upgrade to current technology, and relaunch - even with reduced personnel. Beyond propaganda value, benefit wouldn't match the effort, most likely.
- Benefits to Cuba: though the station would provide financial income to Cuba, it is unlikely that Russia will  consider the investment mainly out of preserving a strategic relationship with the island's government.
- Technical timetable: while announcing may happen in 2017, implementation will take years - and the 2017 focus for Russia will mainly be on the ME,  and Eastern Europe.
Definition of "announce" criteria in question too vague.

Russia and Cuba both looking toward better relations with the US.  Cuba and Russia reportedly agreed to reopening the facility; although the actual announcement would be more opportunistic at a later date.  If US negotiations are failing, with both Russia and Cuba, an announcement seems more likely.  December 2017 seems too early.
Raul knows where his bread will be buttered from in 2017, and it's not from Putin.

Initial forecast slightly under the consensus. Would Russia like to have an opportunity to have a Cuban presence? Probably if the cost is modest. Is there a reason Raul would not support increasing ties? Probably not (even if Venezuela wasn't a basket case). One problem is the "announce" issue. As a thought experiment, if MadMax wants to set up a listening station in Upper Slobovia, would he announce it? Probably no reason to, but it could happen anyway. (Before things get too far along with this question, is the "announce" really necessary or useful as a question criteria. I suppose I just haven't carped about much in awhile and just needed to.) Second, is such a site particularly useful to Russia from a technical perspective. Not sure the case can be made for that.

The move had been announced earlier in 2014 but never finalised. Russia is said to have made heavy investments to modernise the plant and waived debt to Cuba in exchange for it. Maybe (who knows if we will ever know) the recent opening of the US towards Cuba was a move to delay such reopening? If so, Mr Trumps unhappy remarks on Mr Castro's death and generally less opened moves towards Cuba might accelerate the process again. If Trump continues unwinding the US' opening towards Cuba I'll raise my probability, if he continues in Obama's steps I'll lower it.

Russia has been talking a lot lately about basing rights in strategic spots around the globe, from Egypt to Vietnam to Cuba to Iran. The intent behind these explorations is fairly straightforward: When locked in a multi-theater confrontation with the United States, what better way for the Russian bear to trample the U.S. security umbrella than with a growing military footprint? As we learned during the Cold War, Cuba is another strategic place to plant a foreign military base. It has taken Washington decades to normalize its relations with Havana as a long-term insurance strategy to keep the island out of adversarial foreign hands. Consequently, Russia's talk of reopening its old military facilities in Cuba must be taken with a grain of salt. Now that Venezuela's economy is collapsing, Havana's quest to find a new source of energy shipments and economic patronage will become even more urgent. Cuba is still counting on the United States to get it out of this rut by lifting the trade embargo, a prospect Havana will be reluctant to jeopardize, especially when Russia cannot be expected to subsidize it as it did during the Cold War. Still, Havana can use the rumors of Russia returning to Cuba to prod the United States into following through with the normalization process.

Putin and Trump will spend 2017 developing common ground and looking to accept spheres of interest worldwide.   That will mean Cuba as well as the old SU eastern Europe areas not being allowed to turn into conflict or disputes.  Avoiding reasons not to put up embargoes and lowering ones already in place will be the theme for 2017.

Open sources provide no clear indication regarding the status of Lourdes SIGINT Center in Cuba.  It provides contradictory data regarding closing and re-opening of the Center in Cuba.  Additional information indicates that the Nicaraguan state has successfully agreed to and has implemented a SIGINT center within its territory.  Since the distance between Nicaragua and Cuba is 1,241 km (771 miles) and the range of the SIGINT is unknown in open sources (an estimate of 78+ miles), the trajectory of the SIGINT would reach its targets within the United States.   There is no logical reason to believe that SIGINT would be Implemented within Nicaragua without reaching its target (the United States) since other territories have significantly less strategic interest to the Russians.

I think not.  At this particular moment in history, Raul doesn't need support from Russia and probably would just as soon not unnerve his new pals in the US.   The big unanswered question is how much Putin can dupe Trump into going along with, how soon, and in exchange for what.  Having as he does no idea about the issues,  the attention span of a gerbil, and a pack of musty old cold-war advisors, Trump could easily be persuaded to deep-six the new Cuba arrangement, which might very well turn Young Castro back toward Moscow.  However, I don't think this will come to fruition in this particular form during this Q. I should probably apologize.  Sorry, gerbils.

Starting at 5%.  This seems pretty unlikely for 3 reasons: 1) Fairly low base rate.  Not sure what exact stats are, but this facility has been closed since '01.  The RT article in qn description w/ rumor base is re-opening is from May '15 and obviously hasn't happened yet.  Even assuming Russia would like to reopen the center, what are the odds it happens in any given 12 mo period (I don't know - but has to be <33% in this one example, even if we assume the base does in fact re-open in 2017).  I'd guess it's really more like 10-20% or something even assuming that the Russian intent to re-open is there. 2)  Related to point 1, if it does re-open, what are the odds we get definitive evidence that it has?  Again, I don't know, but I assume even the Trump administration would frown upon such a step (and may not publicly admit that it has allowed it to take place even if internally it knows Lourdes has re-opened), so we may be left in the dark w/ only rumors and no official confirmation (from either side) even in the bull case where base reopens.  I don't have an exact factor, but will say 50-50 shot that if base indeed re-opens that we get definitive public confirmation in the same year. 3) Finally (and most importantly?), given advances in technology, how relevant/useful is a radio signal listening center like this?  I honestly don't know, but we have abundant public evidence of Russia's current intelligence gathering (and influencing) activities in the united states.  It seems to me they can get their hands on quite a lot of useful information without a base like this.  How much can you really learn anymore with one of these stations?  I would imagine most military/intelligence communications are encrypted and not vulnerable to interception.  Most public / unprotected communications can fairly easily be found out by anyone with the will/resources from abroad, so does that lower the value of a station like this?  I'm not an expert.  I'll try to learn more and update, but for now just leaving this as a percentage factor that there's a chance (will start at 50-50) that those with an intelligence background would say a station like this is of low value today (and thus much lower probability they will re-open). So approx math I'm starting with is:  ~20% base rate it happens in 2017 (assuming russians want the base) x 50% chance Russians actually even want the base that badly x 50% shot of public confirmation if base opened = 5%. To play devil's advocate against myself, best argument I could see for other side is that my base rate math is flawed, since 2017 might be a particularly good year for russia to try to re-open. It isn't going to be easy for Trump to call Putin on stuff without looking wrong (or weak) which he won't do.  If Putin opens the base, what is Trump really going to do about it?  Hard to see him totally reversing course and taking a hardline against Russia.  More likely he just brushes off and says it doesn't matter (or possibly just deny that it is open, per my point 2).  So, anyways, I feel fine about my 5%, but do acknowledge that the base rate formulation could be a flawed way to look at it since all years are not equal.
I will have to go with a SuperForecasting "Probably Not"option of happening based on the increased relations established between the USA and Cuba in 2016.
